IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
Maryland State Police - Easton Barrack (I), Marked Patrol Vehicle I-59 which is equipped with a mobile recording device. 

 

Defendant: Miguel Martinez  

Date of Birth: 09/08/1989

Date of Arrest: 10/08/2023

Time of Arrest: 1649

NO LICENSE

 

Trooper’s Training/Experience:

  • Trained in administering Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through the Eastern Shore Criminal Justice Academy, the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. 

  • Trained and certified to operate RADAR and LIDAR through the Centreville Police Department and the Maryland State Police. 

  • Certified in Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (ARIDE) through the Eastern Shore Criminal Justice Academy. 

  • Certified Field Training Officer

  • Caroline County Deputy for four years and six months, reaching the rank of Deputy First Class. 

  • Maryland State Trooper for 1 year.

 

Phase 1: Vehicle in Motion

 

On Sunday,,October 08, 2023, at approximately 1641 hours, I, Trooper C. Cooper #7501, was on patrol in the area of Marvel Road at Cool Spring Road, Marydel, Caroline County, Maryland 21649. 

 

While on patrol I observed a vehicle, later identified as a green 2002 Mazda Protege, displaying Delaware temporary registration XF441723, approach the intersection of Marvel Road at Melville Road. After the vehicle came to a complete stop I observed the vehicle spin its rear tires as the vehicle accelerated. I then began to follow the vehicle and observed it to have an inoperable third brake light as it slowed down to turn right onto Zion Road. I then conducted a traffic stop on the vehicle in the area of Zion Road at Schultz Road. 

 

Prior to the vehicle coming to a complete stop I observed the operator/sole occupant of the vehicle reach down towards the passenger side floorboard. After doing so the operator continued to look back at me while coming to a stop. 

 

Phase 2: Personal Contact 

 

Once the vehicle stopped I made contact with the operator, identified as Miguel Martinez, only after having to knock on the window, even though he watched me approach in the side view mirror. While advising Martinez for the reasoning of the traffic stop, I observed his eyes to be red and glassy. I also detected the strong odor of an air freshener type spray coming from the vehicle. TFC. J. Griffin was also on scene and conducted a passenger side approach. TFC. J. Griffin advised me that he observed a black plastic bag containing alcoholic beverages lying within the front passenger side floorboard. 

 

I requested that Martinez provide me with his license and registration information, at which time he stated he did not have a license or the registration. Due to my observations of the red glassy eyes and Martinez moving to the passenger side floorboard, which resulted in TFC. J. Griffin observed alcohol in that location, I requested that he exit the vehicle. 

 

Once Martinez exited the vehicle, I detected the odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from his breath and person. I then asked Martinez if he had been drinking, at which time he stated that he consumed two, 12 ounce Modello beers, approximately an hour prior to driving. After Martinez admitting to consuming alcohol, I requested that he perform Standardized Field Sobriety Tests (SFSTs). Martinez agreed to perform SFSTs. 

 

Phase 3: Pre-Arrest Screening 

 

The evaluation was performed on flat level ground, free of debris, daylight and approximately 60 degrees. All emergency vehicles on scene had deactivated their front facing lights during the tests. 

 

Medical Conditions - Martinez stated none. 

Injuries - Martinez stated none. 

 

Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus (4/6 Clues): 

 

The first test given was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus Test. The tip of my finger was used as the test’s stimulus and held approximately 12 inches from Martinez’s eyes. He was instructed to look straight ahead, keeping his head still while following and focusing on the tip of the stimulus with his eyes until told to stop. His eyes were equal in size and showed equal tracking with no resting nystagmus. Martinez was asked if he understood the test and the instructions to which he stated, “Yes.”

 

Lack of Smooth Pursuit - Present in both eyes. 

Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation - Present in both eyes. 

Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees - Not present. 

Vertical Nystagmus - Not present. 

 

Walk and Turn (4/8 Clues):

 

Prior to Martinez performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Martinez was instructed to place his right foot directly in front of his left foot and touch heel to toe. He was instructed and demonstrated to place his hands flat at his sides and remain in that position until told to begin. He was advised to take nine (9) steps on a straight-line touching heel to toe on every step. He was instructed to keep his hands flat at his sides, keep his eyes focused on his feet and to count every step aloud. On the ninth step, Martinez was explained and demonstrated to keep his lead foot on the line, take a series of small steps to turn around and completely turn around. Martinez was again explained and demonstrated the second series of nine (9) steps were to be performed identical to the first series. He was instructed that once he began the test that he was not to stop walking until the test was completed, his hands down by his sides, look down at his feet, and count each step out loud. Martinez was asked if he understood the test and the instructions to which he stated, “Yes.”

 

Instructional Stage:

 

Martinez did not remain in the instructional position. 

 

Walking Stage (1st nine):

 

Martinez missed heel to toe and took a total of 10 steps. 

 

Turn:

 

Martinez did not complete the turn satisfactorily. 

 

Walking Stage (2nd nine):

 

Martinez missed heel to toe and took a total of 11 steps. 

 

One Leg Stand (2/4 Clues):

 

Prior to Martinez performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be performed. He was instructed to stand with his heels together and hands down by his sides while the instructions were given. When instructed to start, he was to raise the foot of his choice (left foot), off the ground approximately six (6) inches. While his leg was raised he was to keep his leg straight, watch his raised foot, and to count out loud by thousands (one thousand-one, one thousand-two) and to continue the test until told to stop. Martinez was asked if he understood the test and the instructions to which he stated, “Yes.”

 

Balance and Counting Stage: 

 

Martinez raised his right arm and swayed side to side. 

 

Preliminary Breath Test (PBT): Martinez refused. 

 

Arrest:

Based on the following, I had reason to believe Martinez was driving a motor vehicle under the influence:

 

  • Odor of an alcoholic beverage on his breath and person. 

  • Martinez admitted to consuming alcohol. 

  • Glassy eyes. 

  • Clues during SFSTs. 

  • Alcohol within the vehicle. 

 

Due to my observations, I concluded that Martinez was driving under the influence of alcohol and unable to operate a vehicle safely. At approximately 1649 hours, on Sunday, October 8, 2023, I placed Martinez under arrest for driving under the influence of alcohol. Martinez was placed in the front seat per department policy of my patrol vehicle. While on scene I played the Spanish audio version of the DR-15 and provided Martinez with a copy to follow along. At the completion of it being played, Martinez agreed to take the intoximeter test. 

 

I then transported Martinez to the Maryland State Police - Centreville “S” Barrack, where Cpl. B. Baker completed the intoximeter test. At the completion of the intoximeter test, Cpl. B. Baker advised me that Martinez provided three (3) insufficient breaths, which resulted in it being a refusal. 

 

Martinez was later released on citation and provided a copy of all paperwork. It should be noted that Martinez did not have a valid license, the vehicle he was operating was unregistered and did not have valid insurance. It was towed from the roadside by 404 Auto Repair. 

 

All above events occurred in Caroline County, Maryland.
